newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call money up on bond outflows.
newsitem.headline: Indian call money up on bond outflows.

text.p: Indian call money was quoted in the 7.0-7.5 percent range in early trade Thursday, up from Wednesday's close of 5.0-5.25 on funds outflows towards a bond auction, dealers said.
The Reserve Bank of India auctioned 30 billion rupees of three-year federal government bonds on Wednesday and received bids for 57.45 billion. It acccepted bids for 30 billion.
Payment by successful bidders in on Thursday.
"The outflows (towards the bond) take place today," said a dealer at a foreign bank. "This has slightly squeezed funds supply in the market and pushed rates up."
Other dealers said liquidity had not been affected much and that lenders were driving rates up.

"Supply of funds is still good," said a dealer. "The bond auction received bids far in excess of the notified amount. This shows that enough money is floating around. Rates are being driven up by lenders."
He said he expected rates to start drifting down and to end below 7.0 percent by close of trade.
"Call money should be around 6.0-6.5 percent by tomorrow," the dealer said.
